documents.title: that 's it from juliette
text: guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:44pm goodbye all !
thanks for your questions and i hope to continue the conversation another time .
au revoir !
you can see her in antigone at the king 's theatre in edinburgh , as part of this year 's international festival .
many thanks to her and for everyone 's questions .
fionaabyrne asks : playing such an incredibly intense , demanding role such as antigone must be thoroughly exhilarating , and , at times , exhausting .

do you find the stage a more satisfying venue for exploring these characters , given that you have the gift of a longer run to deepen things and find out about your character anew each night - and how does portraying equally fascinating people on screen feel different ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:28pm it is exhausting but i ca n't stop it !
the greeks are relentless but the need of telling those myths are part of my joy and honour !

documents.title: `` i 'm an inextrovert â try it ! ''
text: brittanyfitzmaurice asks : bonjour , juliette !
i am a big fan of your work .

guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:18pm inextrovert !
try it !
diarmuid o'hanlon asks : will you work with leos carax again ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:17pm yes
nicky johns asks : frivolous question - i 've always been intrigued by that moment in the cafe in three colours where you tip the espresso over the vanilla ice cream .
does the result taste good ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:16pm i ca n't remember the ice-cream i probably don t see my films enough ! !
coopsterman asks : can you solve a long running argument with my girlfriend ?
how exactly is the correct way to pronounce your second name ?
a ) binoche - ssshhb ) binoche - chaaay guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:15pm and the winner is binosssshhhhhhhhh
andrea de oliveira asks : hi juliette , i met you and kiã©slowski once at film festival in sao paulo , brazil .
i just said hi : ) did n't know much english and you were extremely nice , it was the movie blue at festival .
i worked at a video store at the time , and i was only 17 .
i love kieslowski 's movies .
the combination in blue of you and kiã©slowski 's work was unspeakable .
it 's a masterpiece due to your so intense , sincere , yet daring acting .
to this day i watch blue hundred times i am able to see and feel all the rollecaster of emotions , and you barely had any dialogue in the movie .

or julie is you ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:13pm thank you very much , but i 've never been to brazil !
feelinglistless asks : what attracted you to bee season ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:11pm the story .
unfortunately i think that my character in the editing was not really understood , also they made a decision on focusing on the daughter and father 's relationship .
haigin88 asks : in chocolat you play a french woman who lives and works in france yet she speaks english all of the time .
how does this make you feel ?
do you feel embarrassed at the silliness of this strange situation ?
do you feel altruistic in helping non-french speakers understand a french-set story easily ?
or are your feelings somewhere in-between ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 1:09pm the story of chocolat is universal enough to go beyond the language in my opinion .
it did n't bother me to play in english as a french character in this film :
andrewdavidboyle asks : what is the most enlightening book you have ever read ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:47pm enlightening ?
recently i read symbolism of the human body of annick de souzennelle , that will come out in autumn in english .
reading this book was a real strong experience because she goes through the whole body , feet to head , in giving different significations throughout different traditions .
she uses the sephirot tree in order to follow a possible evolution .

documents.title: `` regret is not a feeling i live with ''
text: liamr asks : is there an film you did that you wish you had n't ?
or if that is a silly question , is there an opportunity you turned down which you wish you had n't ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:40pm regret is not a feeling i live with .
i did make mistakes but i hope i learned from them .
usually the difficulties make you feel more what you need and what you do n't need .
it allows you to grow and really follow your intuition .
making choices from your head is never a good choice but being in touch with your heart , no matter what mistakes you 've made , you will never regret it .
when you see a film that has been acted by another actress and that is very well acted - i have always experienced joy .
because great art makes you feel better .
it never diminishes you .
i went through times that were not always easy but i have always tried to be in a creative mode through theatre , films , painting or dance .
when you make that choice , there is no need of jealousy .
ongley asks : what was the thing you enjoyed the most about filming in caltagirone and what attracted you to l'attesa in the first place ?

guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:35pm when i read the script of l'attesa i was touched by the story first and i met with the first-time director piero messina who had an intense presence and watched his short film where i could see he had a strong sense of vision .
it is always risky to do a first feature film but it was worth risking this film with him .
and now that we are selected in competition in the venice film festival i think i did n't make a mistake !
i loved sicily and always feel very frustrated when i leave because i feel that i never have enough time to really know places where i film because i am so busy with the work .
i have been so busy in edinburgh but this morning i have found someone to do a house swap with so i can come back and visit with my family .
i want to do the same thing in sicily .
jill barker asks : do you think that your character in clouds of sils maria is a method actor ?
and if so , did she choose to use the method earlier as well as later in life ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:30pm i 've been working throughout my career in different ways and i love to renew my approach to the work at every single experience .
it makes me more alive .
for sils maria i worked with this wonderful american coach , susan batson , to prepare as the role was difficult and wordy .
the production and the director did n't allow me to have a language coach which was a challenge for me but i had an assistant , lara , who really helped me to go through the dialogue .
to try and answer your question about the method i 've always been interested in all methods .
and i 've been inspired by a lot of approaches .
starting with a sensation and a memory is always feeding your presence in front of the camera but i love to use the imagination as well , and your own personal `` plugs '' .

for example , while i 'm playing antigone , i made a special relationship with la duse , who was an amazing italian stage actress at the beginning of the 20th century , and who influenced the acting at the time .
she always started with her heart and the need of nakedness , rawness and truth was coming out of the pores of her skin .
so the transmission of acting can happen in many different ways - you have to invent your own !

documents.title: `` three colours blue was one of the most joyful experiences i 've had on a movie set ''
text: as soluzione says : perhaps it 's not a question ( unless you wish to expand on your performance and kieslowski as a director ) , but by chance i watched three colours blue last week and i was once again reminded of how remarkable as an actress you truly are guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:23pm well thank you !

as an actor , when you have a director who is so clear in his way of filming , when you have a dp who knows so well how to film , when you have great actors and a crew that is present in the work then good can only come out of you !
the theme of the film was particularly close to my heart because one of my best friends had lost a child , and husband and i dedicated this film to her and her child .
again , it was one of the most joyful experiences i 've had on a movie set .

i think what deepens my performance is the way that krzysztof edited the film by adding , at the end of the scene , a black screen so that the audience would have time to take in what is happening inside of my character .
for krzysztof , the editing was the key for directors because they did n't have to bother with actors and the crew and the weather !
he was alone , free , and could give the right rhythm of the story .
id0533161 asks : hey juliette , also on a michael haneke tip , another of my favourite films is code unknown .
can you tell us a little about your experiences of working with him on that one ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:15pm code unknown is one of my favourite films - and for haneke as well .
so i am happy that you are asking about this particular film !
it shows how cowardly we can be in everyday basic life .
the contrast between the western way of thinking and poorer countries .
it was my first time working with haneke and i was blown away by his ability to see what was happening in an actor - it was as if he was scanning me !

he himself experienced acting in different workshops so he knows how difficult it is but also he knows the journey that the actor goes through so he can really get inside of the performances with details and knowledge .
it was a very joyful shooting and that 's why we did hidden together afterwards .
llivracnhoj asks : hi juliette .
for me , one of your most brilliant and nuanced performances is in hidden ( cachã© ) .
what 's your understanding ( or interpretation ) of the ending , i.e the final scene , of that film ?
guardian contributor juliettebinoche 12 august 2015 12:05pm as you know , haneke does not like to give answers but likes to have the audience think for themselves and make their own judgment .
that is why i never try to resolve the dilemma !
not having an answer makes you think even more about different possibilities .
a film is not always to resolve a dilemma but to open your mind through it and put you in touch with your own feelings .

documents.title: post your questions for juliette binoche
text: after a successful european tour , juliette binoche is playing sophocles ' tragic heroine antigone at the edinburgh international festival in ivo van hove 's production , which was broadcast earlier this year by the bbc .

it 's one of the festival 's hottest tickets and binoche 's antigone joins her long list of striking characters including julie vignon in the three colours trilogy , vianne rocher in chocolat , and her oscar-winning turn as hana in the english patient .

as well as her forays into hollywood ( godzilla , dan in real life ) , she has given unforgettably intense performances in some of the most celebrated european films of recent years such as michael haneke 's hidden and bruno dumont 's camille claudel 1915 .
juliette will join us in edinburgh to answer your questions in a live webchat from 12 noon bst on wednesday 12 august .
post them in the comments below , and she 'll answer as many as possible .
